712931f-a.text:
East 42nd Street, at the N.E. corner of Vanderbilt Ave.

Construction of the old Grand Central Terminal, rear view, Park Avenue (then Fourth Avenue), from 45th to 42nd Streets. This part of the building will be the great train shed towering over the platforms. On the left, outside of the station on the east side, the old New York and Harlem Railroad tracks go down to Madison Square via the Park Avenue tunnel under Murray Hill.
1869
Ewing Galloway.

712933f-a.text:
East 42nd Street, north side, west from and including Depew Place to Vanderbilt Ave., showing the Grand Central Depot. Note the horse
drawn street cars on 42nd Street.
Te..atk  About 1875.
C0ift of H. D. Jewett.

712934f-a.text:
Grand Central Railroad Station, 42nd Street East and
Vanderbilt Avenue showing.
111- King
Urbrocks Collection.
re, 7i7

712960f-b.text:
60 to 72 East 42nd Street, south side, west of Pershing Square (Park Avenue), showing the Lincoln Building site under preparation. Here, formerly stood the old seven story structure housing the LLincoln National Bank and Safe Deposite Co. and the five story Hotel Athens. Both of these extended through the block to 41st Street and their demolition has ooened a view of buildings on the south side of that street. The dark structure to the left is the old Murray Hill Hotel. Adjonig same are two low buildings numbered 58 & 56 E. 41st Street. The Chemists Club is No. 50-54, the ten story dominant. A four story affair, No. 46-48 separates this from the twelve story office building, No. 40-44. The latter adjofng the . E. corner structure at
Mndison Avenue.
View 1: August 22, 1928
'. L. Sperr
NO REPRODUCTIONS  Views 2-6: Summer 1928
P. L. Sperr

712936f-a.text:
East 42nd Street at the N.E. corner of Vanderbilt Ave. Old Grand Central Terminal, at the northern end of Park Ave., from 42nd to 45th Streets. The view at the left is north on Vanderbilt Ave. At the right may be seen the station of the 42nd Street elevated spur from Third Ave. Immediately adjoining it on the north side of 42nd Street is the archway through which trains, bound for Madison Square via the Murray Hill-Park Ave. tunnel, used to emerage from the Grand Central. When this station was built in 1871 the railroad began by leaving the engine here and having the cars pulled down to Madison Square by horse; some years before the date of this picture even that had ceased, and this station became a terminal for all trains. At the N.E. corner of Vanderbilt Ave. and 42nd Street, notice the florist's shop and the
barber's, also the two ladies carrying parasols.
About 1892.

712937f-a.text:
E. 42nd Street, at the N. E. corner of Vanderbilt Avenue, showing the (lst) Grand Central Depot of 1871. Tho photographer is viewing due northward from the line of Park Avenue.
About 1893
Gift of Urbrock Collection
H. N. Tiemann, photo

Neg. # 1428

712939f-a.text:
E. 42nd Street, at the N. E. corner of Vanderbilt Avenue, showing the (1st) Grand Central Depot on this site. This was
erected in 1871 and replaced in 1900.
About 1893
H. N. Tiemann, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection

712938f-a.text:
E. 42nd Street, at tho N. E. corner of Vanderbilt Avenue, showing the (1st) Grand Central Depot. This structure, erected in 1871 was replaced in 1900. The photographer is viewing due northward from the line of Park Avenue. Depew Place is on the right
and Vanderbilt Avenue at the left.
About 1893
Gift of Urbrock Collection
H. N. Tiemann, photo
Neg. # 2447

712940f-a.text:
42nd Street, east from and including Vanderbilt Avenue, showing old Grand Central Terminal, also the Lincoln Safe Deposit Company building at old No. 38 East 42nd Street, south side, with a wing being added at No. 40. The building number will later be changed to 60 East 42nd Street.
About 1895.
Elmendorf Photo,
from Ewing Galloway.

New # 1466.

712941f-a.text:
o. 42nd St. at n.e. corner of Vanderbilt Ave.
Early 1900s.
From Department of Public Relations, New York Central Systew, 466 Lexington Ave., New York 17, N.Y. Please give credit line to New York Central System.

712942f.text:
42nd Street and Vanderbilt Avenue, showing the old Grand
Central Depot being torn down.
1900
Neg. # 719

712943f-a.text:
E. 42nd Street, at the N.E. corner of Vanderbilt Avenue,
showing the 3rd Grand Central Station on this site.  The photographer
is viewing northward in the line of Park Avenue, which at this point
is identified as Pershing Square.  Note at the left the Belmont Hotel
and at the right the cleared corner upon which will rise the Pershing
Square Building.  The "N1" spur on 42nd Street has not been removed
as yet.

1914

Gift of Urbrock Collection
Irving Underhill
NO REPRODUCTIONS
Neg. #720

712944f-a.text:
East 12nd Street at the N.E. corner of Vanderbilt Ave. Grand Central Station, Park Avenue at 42nd Street, showing the new automobile viaduct, which in this view seems only recently completed. If that is true, then the new Interborough Subway lines have just been opened (notice passengers from the new Grand Central express station coming up to the street in the foreground), the name Pershing Square for this block has just been suggested by John E. Bowman, and not yet officially adopted, General Pershing is still distinguishing himself in the War, and this is
Summer, 1918.

Neg #1430

712945f-a.text:
Grand Central Station
c.1921
Gift of: Ms Virginia F Clair
New Rochelle, NY
S. 1976

712946f-a.text:
East 42nd Street at the N.E. corner of Vanderbilt Ave.
Grand Central Station and Park Avenue, north from and including 42nd Street, seen from the roof of the newly completed Pershing Square Building on the east side of Park Avenue where the Grand Union Hotel stood prior to 1914.  On the right may be seen the old spur from the Third Avenue "L", to be taken down in 1924, and a glimpse of the little alley, between Grand Central Station and the Hotel Commodore, which used to be DePew Place, balancing Vanderbilt Avenue.
Traffic is quite light over the viaduct, even if it is only 11:15 a.m. Both north and south bound traffic travels around the west shoulder of the station, between 42nd and 45th Streets; the viaduct to the east is yet a dead-end leg, for the convenience of the Commodore Hotel.  As yet no statue of Commodore Vanderbilt stands in front of the great central window, facing north bound automobile traffic.  Late 1922
Ewing Galloway

723704f-a.text:
Vanderbilt Avenue, west side, from 42nd to 43rd Streets, showing a corner of the Pershing Square Viaduct in the right foreground, and a portion of the Hotel Biltmore on the N.W. corner of 43rd Street. The building shown on 42nd Street, to the left of the picture, is the newly erected Liggett-Ley Building on the N.E. corner of Madison Avenue and 42nd Street.
Later views of Vanderbilt Avenue will show that eleven stories have been added to the building which fills the center of this
picture.
About 1922.
Gift of E. M. Jenks.

0rand Central Terminal, 42nd Street at the N.E. corner of Vanderbilt

712959f-b.text:
60 to 72 East 42nd Street, south side, west of Pershing Square (Park Ave.) showing the Lincoln Building site being prepared. The photographer is viewing northward the same to the 42nd Street frontage. This is on a line with Vanderbilt Avenue, a thoroughfare that skirts the west side of Grand Central station, a corner of which is at the right top. To the left is a portion of the building at the N. W. corner. The side wall of the later demolished Hotel Belmont is on the right.
View 1: September 5, 1928
P. L. Sperr
Views 2-6: Summer 1928

712962f-a.text:
42nd Street, west from and including Vanderbilt Avenue. The old Lincoln Safe Deposit Company building at 60 East 42nd Street
(old No. 38) is about to be demolished.
Spring 1928.
Ewing Galloway.

723703f-a.text:
(1)
Vanderbilt Avenue, north from 42nd Street, showing the Pershing Square Viaduct on the west side of the Grand Central Station, and the new New York Central Building from 45th to 46th Streets, nearing completion.
This view is from the roof of the Chemists' Club on 41st Street, and does not show the west side of Vanderbilt Avenue.
September 5, 1928.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.
(2)
The same, looking almost straight up Vanderbilt Avenue, and
showing less of the New York Central Building.
September 5, 1928.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.
(3)
A slightly later view, from the Murray Hill Hotel at Park Avenue and 41st Street, showing the west side of Vanderbilt Avenue. The Hotel Biltmore (opened January 1914) occupies the block from 43rd to 44th Streets, and the Yale Club (built about 1914) is on the N.W. corner of 44th Street.
October 22, 1928.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

712952f-a.text:
(1)
East 42nd Street, at the N.E. corner of Vanderbilt Ave., as seen from Park Ave. Shown across debris of the former Hotel Belmont, is the Grand Central Station of the N.Y.C.R.h. Note the vehicular viaduct extending from Park Ave., and encircling the station. On the extreme right, appears a portion of the Hotel Commodore. Across the skyline is seen
the tower of the Grand Central Building.
August 25, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, another view.
August 25, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
A limited view, and showing prominently the ornamentation.
February 23, 1931.
P L. Sperr.

712953f-a.text:
East 42nd Street at the N.E. corner of Vanderbilt Ave. Grand Central Terminal, at the northern end of lower Park Ave., from 42nd to 45th Streets; the view at the left is north on the east side of Vanderbilt Ave. The view is nearly the same as that of the old station taken about
1892, but closer and more restricted.
About 1929.
Ewing Galloway.

712950f-c.text:
East 42nd Street, at the N.E. corner of Vanderbilt Avenue, showing the southerly, or main side of the Grand Central Station. Approaching same from Park Avenue at 40th Street, is the ramp that carries traffic around this building to emerge at 46th Street. The photographers vantage point is the old Murray Hill Hotel. At the left foreground is the former Belmont Hotel site. Vanderbilt Avenue starts at that point. Towering above the station is the Grand Central Building where Park Avenue recommences.
August 25, 1931
Views 1, 2, 3
P. L. Sperr

712950f-a.text:

712966f-b.text:
(1)
East 42nd Street, at the S.W. corner of Pershing Square, as seen from Vanderbilt Ave., and showing the demolition of the Hotel Belmont.
June 28, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same from another angle, and showing the west side of Pershing Square (Park Ave), from East 42nd to 41st Streets.
July 12, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same as No. 2, at a later date. Note the Belmont Bar and Outdoor Cafe, as seen from under the raised vehicular viaduct at this point.
September 10, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

712954f-a.text:
East 42nd Street at the N.E. corner of Vanderbilt Ave., showing the Grand Central Railroad Station extending to 45th Street on the latter Ave.  Park Ave. traffic passes on the bridge over East 42nd Street (right) and around Grand Central Station on an elevated vehicular driveway, passing underneath the New York Central Building, at East  45th Street, then resuming its normal course on Park Ave., north from East 46th Street.  The station is the terminal for the New York Central Railroad, and the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad.  It was opened in 1913.
1936
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project

712964f-a.text:
E. 42nd Street, north side, west from Vanderbilt Avenue, as viewed northwestward from the Chanin Bldg, showing prominently the 500 Fifth Avenue Bldg. outlined against the North River and the Jersey Shore.
October 3, 1936.
P.L. Sperr

723710f-a.text:
Vanderbilt Ave., south from, but not including East 47th., to and including 42nd Streets. On the left appears the Grand Central Palace Building with the Grand Central Station receding southward to 42nd Street, at which point the Lincoln Building abruptly terminates the view. On the right, is shown the Roosevelt Hotel (46th to 45th Streets), the Vanderbilt Concourse Building (S.W. corner of 45th Street) and the Hotel Biltmore (44th to 43rd Streets), which is just south of the Yale Club (Building at the N.W. corner of 44th Street, and bearing a dark banner).
1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.

712958f-a.text:
Villa St. is only 4 blocks S. of the Westchester Cross County Parkway.

The present aerie of two of the old Grand Central Eagles on Villa St. Mount Vernon, N.Y.  Like the Mercury on the present Grand Central they're all poised for flight but never fly.

According to a feature article appearing in the N.Y. News magazine Jan. 2, 1966 the above cast iron eagle was one of 16 which once adorned the top of the old Grand Central Station on 42nd St. N.Y.C.  Those birds were added to the remodelled station in 1898.  But only remained on their perch for 5 years. Then were removed when the station was rebuilt in 1903. The News illustrated 9 of the 16 in their present locations. The one above and another are now on Villa St. Mount Vernon, N.Y. (over for map)
